content:
In string theory, the vibrations of strings are not caused by an external source, but rather they are an intrinsic property of the strings themselves. The strings are modeled as one-dimensional objects that can vibrate in different modes, and the different vibrations correspond to different types of particles, such as electrons and quarks.

The vibrations of strings in string theory are described by equations known as the string equations of motion. These equations describe the behavior of strings in space-time and determine the different modes of vibration that are possible. The equations take into account the properties of the strings, such as their tension and mass density, and the interactions between strings and other objects in space-time, such as background fields and other strings.

In this sense, the vibrations of strings in string theory are a result of the properties of the strings themselves and the interactions between strings and other objects in space-time. The strings themselves are the source of their own vibrations, and the different modes of vibration correspond to different types of particles.

Overall, the vibrations of strings in string theory provide a useful mathematical description of the behavior of particles and their interactions, and have led to many new insights and predictions in physics.
